questions.neutral: You made it in one piece?

hobby.message: Urban exploration or just avoiding work?
I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Barely. It’s chaos out there. Everyone’s in a rush now.
I stick to my hobby, keeps me grounded—old film photography.
Difficult lately, with the mural crowds. Too much attention.
Still, I keep shooting. Quietly.
Still in one piece, just more eyes out tonight.
I do analog street photography. Film, not digital—keeps me disconnected from the system.
Mural assemblies pulled in scenes I can’t resist capturing.
Have to stay careful though. Lot of folks want to know who’s watching.
Film’s hard to hide now.
Made it. Had to dodge a Directorate sweep on Komissar Street.
I’m out after hours with my 35mm, shooting candid city moments.
Lately the mural and all the assemblies—I can’t not document it.
Analog only. No data trail, that’s important to me.
Caught a family holding up BCI reports for my lens yesterday.
Roll was full in under an hour. Never seen the city so raw.
Yeah, dodged a checkpoint. Hid my camera under my coat—just in case.
Street photography is my thing, always film—cheap Minolta, black-and-white mostly.
Last week, after the BCI dump, the mural brought out everyone’s truth.
Kids showing bruised knuckles and printouts. People want to be seen now.
The digital guys get nervous, but my stuff never pings the network.
Captured a father reading his whole BCI history aloud. Unfiltered moments, nobody edits.
Makes the risk worth it, honestly.
Just barely. Directorate teams everywhere, looking for anyone with a lens.
I shoot real film—old school street photography, nothing digital. Grew up around surveillance.
After the BCI archives leaked at the mural, I’ve never seen so much honest fear—and hope—in faces.
My camera’s a Minolta X-370 my father hid from asset checks back in '21.
Documenting the assemblies now, before Directorate wipes it all away. Analog shots can’t be erased by the system.
Last night, a woman handed me her childhood BCI record and asked for a portrait.
I archive negatives under a false wall in my apartment. Still got every frame.
With the blackout and the mural, these images might outlast all of us.
hobby_answer: Sure, still using analog.
Hard to find film now with all the commotion.
Lately, I just shoot empty streets. Safer subjects.
System eyes everywhere—except on real negatives.
It's not the time for risks, not even with a camera.
Yeah, analog photography's still my thing.
Film’s almost impossible to get since the blackout crowds.
Pictures I take now are for my eyes only.
People get nervous seeing a lens these days.
Since the BCI chaos, anything can be held against you.
I only shoot from a distance lately.
Analog photography... that’s me. Keeps me grounded when things are wild.
Scored a roll of Ilford on the underground last week.
Since the BCI reset, crowds are fearless—almost begging for a portrait.
Light at the mural was perfect—the faces, the tension... pure history.
I keep prints stashed safe, nowhere digital touches.
Lost my badge, but not my eye. That’s what matters.
Nothing like a snapshot the system can’t erase.
Always analog. Still got the Minolta, survived three lockdowns and two blackouts.
With the BCI dump, people aren't scared of cameras—for once.
Took portraits at the mural—tears, laughter, stories all in a single frame.
Face of a woman confronting her score—burned into silver halide forever.
Since losing my clearance, this is how I still contribute: documenting what’s buried.
I keep backup film in a flowerpot at Bar 101... just in case.
Darkroom's my safehouse now—no signals, no prying algorithms.
You wouldn't believe some of the prints I’ve got.
Yeah, analog photography—the closest thing I have to therapy or protest.
First camera was a Zenit my father confiscated, taught me all the tricks.
After the BCI files dropped, people lined up for portraits by the mural.
Teenagers wanted proof they existed before the scores defined them.
Moments like that—nobody trying to smile pretty, just real.
I’ve hidden rolls in bread bags, under floor tiles, all over town.
They wiped my media credentials, but not my negatives or my memory.
Once, Halden’s own fixer posed for me, shaking—no one knew.
Maybe my archive will be the only honest record left if this system buries itself.
